column1: Inheritance allows the creation of new classes based on existing classes, inheriting their properties and methods.
Inheritance in Java is achieved by using the 'inherits' keyword followed by the name of the superclass.
A subclass can add its own properties and methods in addition to the ones inherited from the superclass.
A subclass cannot override the methods inherited from its superclass in Java.
The 'extends' keyword in Java is used to define a subclass (derived class) of a superclass (base class).
In Java, a class can inherit from multiple classes simultaneously, achieving multiple inheritance.
The 'super' keyword in Java is used to call the constructor and methods of the superclass.
In Java, the 'super' keyword is used to define a subclass.
Abstract classes in Java cannot be instantiated directly.
Abstract classes in Java are defined using the 'abstraction' keyword.
An abstract method in Java is declared without an implementation in the abstract class.
In Java, abstract methods are defined using the 'virtual' keyword.
A subclass of an abstract class must implement all the abstract methods declared in the abstract class.
In Java, a subclass of an abstract class can choose not to implement some of the abstract methods.
A class hierarchy in Java represents the relationship between classes through inheritance.
In a class hierarchy, a subclass can only inherit from one superclass.
In Java, a class can inherit from another class and implement multiple interfaces at the same time.
In Java, a class hierarchy is created using the 'hierarchy' keyword.
The 'protected' access modifier in Java allows access within the same class, subclasses, and the same package.
In Java, the 'public' access modifier restricts access to within the same class only.
The 'final' keyword in Java is used to define a class that cannot be subclassed.
In Java, a final method can be overridden by its subclasses.
The '@Override' annotation in Java is used to indicate that a method is being overridden from a superclass.
In Java, the '@Overload' annotation is used to indicate method overriding.
In object-oriented programming, encapsulation is the practice of hiding internal details of an object and providing a controlled interface.
In Java, encapsulation is achieved by using the 'encapsulate' keyword.
Constructors in Java are used to initialize the object's state when it is created.
In Java, constructors have a return type.
